LibraryAsset.title: phptest-All/Nothing Thinking
LibraryAsset.description: Black/white or all/nothing thinking traps lead to missing the gray areas that are what most of life is about.  This brief article highlights how to change that pattern through awareness.
LibraryAsset.content:
It’s a common thinking pattern for many people to categorize events, people, and situations in a polarized or good/bad sort of way.  Unfortunately that can often lead to missing many of the shades of gray, or in between aspects.   This black or white way of thinking most often distorts the reality of an event, person, or situation.   Very few things in life are all or nothing, always, or never.

The purpose of this task is to monitor how often you might use one or another of the common polarized ways of thinking, and then change that thought (or even verbal speech) to a more realistic word.  For example: if you hear yourself say “I never get appreciated for ….” Pause and consider if that’s really true.  Never means NEVER.  Even one instance where you were shown appreciation, even a little bit, means that ‘never’ is not correct.  Change your internal thought or external speech to, “I rarely get appreciated for …” or it may be more correct to say, “I don’t get appreciated as much as I’d like.” 
   
Your objective in this task is to observe for the Polarizing Key Words (the most common ones are listed below) in your thoughts or in your conversations.  Each time you notice a Polarizing Key Word catch the thought or in conversation and correct it with a modifier. If you identify more Polarized Key Words add them to the list.

All 
Nothing 
Everything
 
Always 
Never 
None 
Completely
Entirely 
Nobody 
Whole (day, event)

Modifier words: Most; Few; Many; Frequently; Seldom; Hardly any; Mostly; Largely;

LibraryAsset.title: phptest-5 Whys
LibraryAsset.description: This exercise can be used to understand many personal and relationship issues. While the process is basic, the awarenesses gained can be very valuable.
LibraryAsset.content:
This exercise is based on the model used by Toyota Motor Corporation to identify the root cause of problems encountered during manufacturing cars. Today more than 60 years after this model was created it is being applied to help individuals in various settings identify why problems occur. This exercise can be used to understand many personal and relationship issues.

While the process is basic, the awarenesses gained can be very valuable. You begin by identifying a problem that you are encountering in your life. The issue could be a personal problem, a relationship issue, a challenge with your child, a work problem, or something else you are dealing with.

Example of a problem:

I can’t stop my mind from thinking about what my spouse did to me.

Now it is your turn. Identify a personal issue that you would like to understand better.

Issue I want to address:____________________________________________________________

Begin by asking yourself why that issue is bothering you

Why #1--Example: I feel betrayed. Like he only cares about himself. I am so angry at him.
